title: 2 Easy Ways to Set Up a VPN on iPhone

steps.title: Download a VPN from the App Store.
steps.content: Download a VPN from the App Store. If you just want a VPN for personal use on your iPhone, there are tons of options available in the App Store. Select the option with your favorite features and download it to your iPhone. Most VPNs are available for a low monthly subscription fee, although there are some free options as well. Some highly rated paid VPN apps include NordVPN, SurfShark, and ExpressVPN. A few of the best free options include PrivadoVPN Free, ProtonVPN Free, and Windscribe Free.

steps.title: Create an account.
steps.content: Create an account. Once you’ve installed your VPN, launch the app, sign up for an account, and log in. If you’ve already created an account on the VPN provider’s website, just sign in.

steps.title: Choose a server.
steps.content: Choose a server. Most VPN apps will give you the option to automatically connect to the fastest server. You can also choose your own server if you want to connect to one in a particular location.

steps.title: Connect to the server.
steps.content: Connect to the server. Depending on the VPN you chose, you might see an option that says On , Connect , or something similar. Activate the connection, then enjoy browsing the internet privately on your iPhone.

steps.title: Gather the information you need.
steps.content: Gather the information you need. Most of the time, you won’t need to configure a VPN manually on your iPhone. However, you might need to do this if you’re connecting to a private network for school or work. Ask the network administrator or your supervisor for information such as the protocol type, server name, and remote ID. You may also need to set up a username and password ahead of time.

steps.title: Open the Settings app on your iPhone.
steps.content: Open the Settings app on your iPhone. "Settings" is the grey cog icon ( ) on one of your Home screens. It may also be in a folder named "Utilities" in your App Library.

steps.title: Scroll down and tap General.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap General . It's in the third group of settings.

steps.title: Scroll down and tap VPN & Device Management.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap VPN & Device Management . It’s toward the bottom of the page. This is where you can enter your new VPN settings.

steps.title: Tap VPN.
steps.content: Tap VPN . Here you'll have the option to add a new configuration. The configuration options you enter should be provided to you by your network administrator.

steps.title: Tap Add VPN Configuration….
steps.content: Tap Add VPN Configuration… . This option is at the top of the screen. The "Add Configuration" window will expand.

steps.title: Tap Type and choose a connection type.
steps.content: Tap Type and choose a connection type. This will be dictated by your network configuration. Your available connection types include the following options: [1] X Research source IKEv2 IPSec L2TP

steps.title: Add the rest of your VPN details.
steps.content: Add the rest of your VPN details. Type your VPN's information into the pertinent fields. Depending on the type of connection you're using and your system administrator's configuration settings, this will include some or all of the following information: Description Server Remote ID Local ID Username and password

steps.title: Choose a proxy setting.
steps.content: Choose a proxy setting. Choose one of the three proxy options at the bottom. If your VPN uses a proxy network—that is, a network separate from your own that's used to hide your IP address—you'll need to tap one of the following options at the bottom of your screen: Manual : This option allows you to configure the server, port, and authentication preferences for your proxy. Auto : If you have the specific web address for your chosen proxy, you can paste it into the "URL" section of this option.

steps.title: Tap Done to save.
steps.content: Tap Done to save. You'll see at the top-right corner of the screen. Your VPN should now be configured and ready to turn on.
